channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Officials Market French Economy to China
item.description: French efforts to woo China as an investor reflect the changing balance of power in the global economy.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER

item.title: Dunford Optimistic on Post-Coalition Afghanistan
item.description: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., who assumed command of the international forces in February, said Afghan forces would step up as the coalition’s war ended.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: “You can accuse me of being an optimist and I’ll plead guilty,” said Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., who in February took over as the commander of the international forces in Afghanistan.

item.title: Taliban Bomb Kills at Least 20 at a Pakistan Political Rally
item.description: The attack along the border with Afghanistan was the deadliest so far of the campaign for next Saturday’s national election.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: India Ink: Young, Urban, Educated…and Choosing Not to Vote
item.description: Despite political action committees and awareness campaigns, half of Bangalore’s eligible voters didn’t go to the polls this election.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI
item.media:description: Maria Wajid, 18, was one of the first time voters who voted in Bangalore, Karnataka on Sunday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Some ‘Silent Protests’ in Malaysian Malls After Disputed Election
item.description: Some Malaysians took to the mall to protest silently against a Sunday electoral win by the ruling government coalition, now in power for 56 years; others denounced a charge that a “Chinese tsunami” made the vote closer than usual.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screengrab from the news and events Web site Hype Malaysia, said to be showing a group of "The Silent Walk" protestors in a mall.

item.title: U.S. Accuses China’s Military in Cyberattacks
item.description: The Pentagon explicitly accused China of attacks on government systems and defense contractors, possibly to map “military capabilities that could be exploited during a crisis.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: With Carbon Dioxide Approaching a New High, Scientists Sound the Alarm
item.description: This month atmospheric carbon dioxide levels are likely surpass 400 parts per million. Scientists say that while the number is arbitrary, it’s an important reminder that the climate is changing: When the carbon dioxide level changes, so do global temperatures.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:credit: Stephen Maturen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students in Minneapolis, seeking steps to cut atmospheric carbon levels to 350 parts per million, known as the safe level.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Seeking Visibility for China’s Art
item.description: China is a major art market, but some artists and curators feel it is underrepresented in the world’s major museums and galleries.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A man posed by a sculpture titled "Childhood Horizon," by the artist Chen Wenling, during the three-day Art Beijing Contemporary Art Fair last week.

item.title: The Lede: Social Media Images of Protesters in Moscow
item.description: An opposition protest in Moscow on Monday was extensively documented by the protesters themselves, who posted images and video on social networks of a rally attended by nearly 30,000 people.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and ILYA MOUZYKANTSKII

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ex-Nazi With Link to Auschwitz Is Arrested
item.description: The authorities on Monday arrested a 93-year-old former Nazi soldier, saying that they had evidence he had worked as a guard at Auschwitz and was complicit in murders there.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS COTTRELL

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Tanzania: Suspects in Church Blast Include 4 Saudis
item.description: The authorities said Monday that they had arrested four Saudis and four Tanzanians in connection with the bombing of a Catholic church in Arusha on Sunday that killed 2 people and wounded 60.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: At Least 17 People Killed in Baghdad Attacks
item.description: At least 17 people were killed by three bombs and a grenade attack on a mosque in Baghdad on Monday, medics and the police said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: White House Sticks to Cautious Path on Syria
item.description: The Obama administration insisted it would not veer from its approach, despite strikes near Damascus by Israel and new questions about the use of chemical arms in Syria’s civil war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A Syrian draped in a flag with a portrait of President Bashar al-Assad at an anti-Israeli demonstration Monday in Tehran, Iran.

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Is Aiding Inquiry into Boston Attacks
item.description: Despite a history of strained relations, the United States and Russia have been working effectively to investigate the marathon bombings, American officials said.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: News Analysis: U.S. Intelligence on North Korea Proves Elusive
item.description: At a time when the United States has learned to target drone strikes with increasing accuracy and direct cyberweapons at specific nuclear centrifuges, its understanding of North Korea has gotten worse.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Relatives going to see a patient at a hospital in Pyongyang, North Korea. America’s understanding of the North’s weapons capability has gotten worse.

item.title: From Jungle, Brazil Aims to Extend Its Reach
item.description: The Jungle Warfare Instruction Center, where wild conditions serve to teach lessons, is emerging as a cornerstone of Brazil’s ambition to spread its influence.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers from elite Brazilian units, as well as special operations forces from around the world, vie for spots at the Jungle Warfare Instruction Center at an outpost in the Amazon.

item.title: Israel Allows Gazan Children to Visit Imprisoned Parents
item.description: For the first time since 2006, young Gazans under age 8 were allowed on Monday to visit their parents in Israeli prisons.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Video of Rio Hunt for Drug Trafficker Raises Concern
item.description: The video, taken from a Rio police helicopter and depicting officers spraying the suspect’s car with gunfire in a densely populated area, raised concerns over the heavy use of force by the police.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and TAYLOR BARNES

item.title: Cairo Journal: A Taste of Spring That Reeks of Tradition
item.description: Egyptians commemorate the arrival of spring with the holiday Sham el-Nessim, meaning “smell the breeze,” and its signature dish, a smelly fish called feseekh.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Monday, young men danced on a Nile cruise as Muslims and Christians alike in Egpyt celebrated the ancient spring holiday of Sham el-Nessim.

item.title: The Lede: Share Your Views on Democracy and Stability in Pakistan
item.description: Whether you are living in Pakistan or abroad, join a discussion of what the most important issues are in the country’s general election this weekend.
item.dc:creator: By SHREEYA SINHA
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A night rally for the independent candidate Jamshed Dasti in the district of Muzaffargarh.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,196 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Iran Warns Syrian Rebels After Report of Shrine Desecration
item.description: Iran’s leaders warned of sectarian conflict after reports that Syrian rebels had raided a shrine outside Damascus and made off with the remains of the figure buried there.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK and HANIA MOURTADA

item.title: Russians Protest Prosecutions of Opposition Leaders
item.description: The demonstration occurred on the anniversary of an event that turned violent and precipitated a crackdown by President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Opposition demonstrators held posters of imprisoned protesters during the rally in Bolotnaya Square.

item.title: Israel and Turkey Negotiate Compensation in Flotilla Raid
item.description: Israel negotiated with Turkey over compensation for a deadly commando raid on a Gaza-bound flotilla in 2010, but few involved expected a full reconciliation between the former allies.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: After Close Elections, Uncertainty for Najib Razak of Malaysia
item.description: Though it held on to power in Sunday’s election, the governing National Front coalition failed to win over 50 percent of the popular vote, leaving Prime Minister Najib Razak’s position shaky.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
